item.title: Alex Wild
item.description: Several of us overly online biologists spent years quietly doing an experiment on Twitter, trying to find out if tweeting about new studies from a set of mid-range journals caused an increase in later citations, compared to set of untweeted control articles.Turns out we had no noticeable effect; the tweeted papers were cited at the same rate as the control set. Our paper, headed by Trevor Branch, was published today in PLOS One:#SciComm #Twitter #X #Sciencehttps://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0292201

item.title: Matteo Carandini
item.description: In 1637 Ren√© Descartes published his ‚ÄúDiscourse on the Method‚Äù (the one with "I think, therefore I am"). It introduced a radical way of thinking, which we now call the scientific method. Indeed, the rest of the title is ‚Äú‚Ä¶of Correctly Conducting One‚Äôs Reason and Seeking Truth in the Sciences‚Äù. It was radical. Few people thought that way at the time (Galileo had published his Dialogue only 5 years before). Amazingly, the book also defines the goals of a future discipline: neuroscience! item.title: Matteo Carandini
item.description: We are well on our way. For instance, we have known for a century that those ‚Äúanimal spirits‚Äù are trains of spikes. We have known for decades how spikes can move muscles or represent complex sensory stimuli. And we have learned many more important things since then. But do we have all the facts we need to cross off the rest of the list? Or do we need more radical discoveries ‚Äì on a par with the spike ‚Äì before we can figure out memory, imagination, and those darned ‚Äúinternal passions‚Äù?[4/4]

item.title: L. Rhodes
item.description: The energy consumption of ML-generators is, of course, an environmental issue, but it's also going to be a cost issue. Right now, AI companies are defraying that cost as much as possible, often with VC money, to make integrating it seem like a good deal for companies looking to economize. But at some point, there's going to be a rug pull, and clients who have committed themselves to AI are going to have little choice but to eat that cost or lose time to rolling back their operational investment.
